mdRecord.dcterms:title: Connecting shed, general view
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Wilson, Richard Guy [photographer]
mdRecord.dcterms:publisher: Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site in southeastern Berks County, near Elverson, Pennsylvania, is an example of an American 19th century rural "iron plantation". The covered passageway going from the charcoal house to the bridge house is called the connecting shed. This is where men called fillers worked. Their job was to fill the furnace with the “charge.” A charge was made up of iron ore, charcoaland limestone. Hopewell Furnace was founded in 1771 by ironmaster Mark Bird. -- http://www.nps.gov/hofu/forteachers/upload/sgtour.pdf [work]
